wiki_catalogs.name: Project Overview
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the Opskarta project overview section focused on introducing the operational map format for complex programs. Explain the core philosophy of 'plan-as-code', the separation between operational maps and views, and the benefits of version-controlled planning. Document the project's purpose as an open data format (YAML/JSON) for operational program/cartography. Include both conceptual overviews for beginners explaining what operational maps are and technical details for experienced developers about the specification architecture. Use terminology consistent with the codebase including terms like 'operational map', 'plan', 'views', and 'rendering'. Provide practical examples demonstrating the fundamental workflow from plan creation to multiple view generation. Document the relationship between different specification versions and the overall system architecture.

wiki_catalogs.name: Validation System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive validation system documentation for Opskarta's plan and view file validation tool. Document the three-tier validation approach including syntax validation (YAML parsing), schema validation (JSON Schema compliance), and semantic validation (referential integrity and business rules). Explain validation levels, error reporting mechanisms, and debugging capabilities. Detail the validation rules for required fields, referential integrity checks, dependency cycle detection, and format validation. Include CLI usage examples, parameter descriptions, exit codes, and integration patterns. Document the optional JSON Schema validation mode and custom schema support. Address common validation errors, troubleshooting techniques, and performance considerations for large operational maps.

wiki_catalogs.name: Introduction to Operational Maps
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the operational maps introduction section focused on explaining what operational maps are and why they matter. Explain the fundamental concept of separating 'what exists' from 'how you look at it' - the distinction between the operational map (data model) and views (presentation layers). Document the core philosophy that the operational map serves as the single source of truth for program/project planning. Include practical examples showing how a single operational map can generate multiple views (Gantt charts, dependency graphs, reports). Explain the benefits of this approach including version control, auditability, and multi-perspective analysis. Use terminology consistent with the codebase and provide clear analogies to help beginners understand the concept.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Concepts
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for the core concepts section focused on operational maps philosophy and fundamental principles. Explain the operational maps methodology, the separation between what exists (plan) and how you look at it (views), and the hierarchical relationship system. Document the conceptual framework that distinguishes operational maps from traditional project management tools. Detail the benefits of this approach including version control friendliness, multi-perspective visualization, and extensibility. Include philosophical discussions about work representation, dependency modeling, and temporal planning. Provide conceptual examples showing how operational maps differ from Gantt charts, Kanban boards, and other project management approaches. Address the mental model shift required for adopting operational maps and common misconceptions to avoid. Make content accessible to newcomers while establishing the theoretical foundation for advanced usage.

wiki_catalogs.name: External System Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive external system integration documentation for Opskarta. Detail integration patterns with issue tracking systems (Jira, YouTrack), version control systems (Git), and CI/CD pipelines. Document data synchronization strategies, webhook implementations, and real-time update mechanisms. Explain how to map operational map nodes to external system entities, handle bidirectional synchronization, and manage data conflicts. Include concrete examples of integration configurations, API endpoints, and authentication methods. Address common integration challenges such as data transformation, conflict resolution, and performance optimization. Provide troubleshooting guidance for connectivity issues, permission problems, and data consistency challenges.

wiki_catalogs.name: Basic Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive basic examples documentation for Opskarta focused on fundamental usage patterns. Document the minimal valid plan example showing absolute essential fields and structure. Explain the hello world example demonstrating complete plan and view file creation with proper node hierarchy, status definitions, and visualization setup. Provide step-by-step walkthroughs of each example including file structure analysis, validation commands, and expected outputs. Include practical exercises for beginners to create their first operational maps. Document common mistakes and how to fix them. Address the progression from minimal to complete examples and explain why each additional element matters in the operational map structure.

wiki_catalogs.name: Plan Files (*.plan.yaml)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for plan files documentation focused on the *.plan.yaml format which represents the core operational map data. Document the complete file structure including version field, meta information (id, title), status definitions, and node hierarchies. Explain each field in detail with data types, validation rules, and usage patterns. Include the JSON Schema definition showing required and optional fields. Provide practical examples from hello, advanced, and minimal examples demonstrating proper file formatting. Document the relationship between plan files and views files, node inheritance patterns, and hierarchical organization. Address common validation errors, best practices for maintainable plan files, and integration with version control systems. Include guidance on status management, node categorization, and custom field extensions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Node Hierarchies and Relationships
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for node hierarchies and relationships in operational maps. Document the four node types (summary, phase, epic, task) with their specific roles and use cases. Explain parent-child relationships and how they create the decomposition hierarchy. Detail explicit dependency relationships using the 'after' field and how they differ from hierarchical relationships. Include concrete examples showing node structures, ID references, and relationship patterns. Document validation rules for node relationships, circular dependency detection, and referential integrity requirements. Explain how nodes inherit properties through the hierarchy and how conflicts are resolved. Address best practices for organizing complex operational maps with multiple levels of decomposition.

wiki_catalogs.name: Issue Tracking System Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive issue tracking system integration documentation for Opskarta. Detail integration patterns with Jira, YouTrack, and other issue tracking systems. Document how to map operational map nodes to external system entities using the 'issue' field in plan files. Explain bidirectional synchronization strategies, including status synchronization, dependency mapping, and data transformation between Opskarta and issue tracking systems. Include concrete examples of integration configurations, API endpoints for Jira and YouTrack, and authentication methods. Address common integration challenges such as data conflicts, permission issues, and performance optimization. Provide troubleshooting guidance for connectivity problems and data consistency challenges.

wiki_catalogs.name: Getting Started
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive getting started content for Opskarta focused on quick onboarding and initial setup. Explain installation requirements, environment setup, and basic command-line usage. Document the step-by-step process of creating your first plan file, validating it, and generating Gantt diagrams. Include practical examples using the hello world example from the repository. Provide clear instructions for running validation tools and rendering commands. Address common beginner questions about file formats, basic syntax, and expected outputs. Make content accessible to users with varying technical backgrounds while ensuring they can successfully create and validate their first operational map. Include troubleshooting tips for common setup issues and verification steps to ensure proper installation.

wiki_catalogs.name: Rendering Engine
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed rendering engine documentation for Opskarta's Mermaid Gantt diagram generator. Document the scheduling computation algorithm, automatic date calculation from dependencies, weekend exclusion logic, and business day arithmetic. Explain the rendering pipeline from validated plan data to Mermaid output format. Detail view configuration options, lane organization, status theming with color coding and emoji support. Include CLI usage examples, output formatting options, and integration with visualization tools. Document the Python API for programmatic rendering, data structures used for scheduled nodes, and performance optimization for large datasets. Address customization options, export formats, and troubleshooting rendering issues.

wiki_catalogs.name: Core Philosophy and Benefits
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed content for the core philosophy and benefits section focused on the fundamental principles behind Opskarta. Explain the 'plan-as-code' philosophy and how it transforms project planning from ad-hoc tools to version-controlled artifacts. Document the key benefits including single source of truth, reproducible planning, automated validation, and multi-view generation. Compare Opskarta with traditional project management tools like Jira, Excel, and Confluence, highlighting the advantages of structured data formats. Explain how the separation of concerns between operational maps and views enables flexible presentation and analysis. Include practical examples demonstrating how version control enhances planning workflows and collaboration.

wiki_catalogs.name: File Formats
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for file formats documentation focused on the two primary operational map file types: plan.yaml and views.yaml. Document the complete structure of plan files including version control, meta information, status definitions, and node hierarchies. Detail the views file structure for project association, lane organization, and multi-view support. Explain the relationship between these files and how they work together to create operational maps. Include complete schema definitions from the JSON Schema files, field descriptions, data types, and validation rules. Provide practical examples from the hello and advanced examples showing proper file formatting. Document optional fields, custom extensions, and best practices for maintainable file structure. Address common formatting errors and their solutions. Include guidance on file organization, naming conventions, and version control integration.

wiki_catalogs.name: API Development
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed API development documentation for Opskarta. Document RESTful API patterns for exposing operational map data to external applications, including HTTP methods, URL patterns, request/response schemas, and authentication methods. Explain how to implement CRUD operations for plans and views, data validation endpoints, and rendering APIs. Detail WebSocket implementations for real-time updates, message formats, event types, and connection handling. Include Python API examples showing core functions, exception handling, and data structures. Document API versioning strategies, rate limiting, and security considerations. Provide client implementation guidelines, SDK development patterns, and performance optimization tips for API consumers.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Examples
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for advanced examples section focusing on complex multi-track program scenarios. Document the advanced program example showing sophisticated node hierarchies, multiple status definitions, cross-dependencies, and multi-lane visualization. Explain the organizational patterns used for large-scale projects involving multiple teams, phases, and stakeholders. Provide analysis of the program.plan.yaml structure including nested nodes, status management, and scheduling complexities. Document the corresponding program.views.yaml showing lane organization, team assignments, and perspective variations. Include guidance on scaling operational maps for enterprise-level use cases and managing complexity through proper organization and naming conventions.

wiki_catalogs.name: Views Files (*.views.yaml)
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for views files documentation focused on the *.views.yaml format which controls visualization and presentation of operational maps. Document the complete file structure including project association, gantt view configuration, and lane organization. Explain the relationship with plan files through the meta.id field and how views define different perspectives of the same operational data. Detail each field in the JSON Schema including required and optional properties. Provide practical examples from hello and advanced examples showing multi-view configurations and lane organization. Document view customization options, status-based coloring, and timeline configuration. Address common configuration errors, performance considerations for large datasets, and best practices for maintainable view definitions. Include guidance on organizing multiple views for different stakeholders and integrating with external systems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Status Management System
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive documentation for the status management system in operational maps. Detail how statuses are defined in the statuses section and referenced by nodes. Document status properties including labels, colors, and semantic meanings. Explain the flexible nature of status workflows and how they can be customized per project. Include examples of status definitions and their usage in nodes. Document status validation rules and referential integrity requirements. Explain how statuses integrate with rendering systems and visualization. Address best practices for status design, naming conventions, and maintaining consistency across large operational maps.

wiki_catalogs.name: Version Control System Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create detailed version control system integration documentation for Opskarta. Document Git integration patterns for storing operational map files, including branching strategies for alternative plans and scenarios. Explain how to leverage Git's diff capabilities for tracking changes in operational maps, managing concurrent modifications, and maintaining version history. Include examples of Git workflows for Opskarta files, branch naming conventions for different scenarios ('what if' scenarios), and merge strategies for collaborative planning. Address conflict resolution when multiple team members modify the same operational map, automated backup strategies, and integration with Git-based CI/CD pipelines.

wiki_overview.content:
Now I have enough information to generate a comprehensive project analysis. Let me create the blog post:

<blog>

# Opskarta: Open Specification for Operational Maps

## Project Introduction

Opskarta is an open specification and toolkit for creating operational maps as structured data artifacts. The project addresses a fundamental challenge in project management: maintaining a clear, evolving picture of work across multiple systems and stakeholders without losing structural coherence during parallel editing.

### Purpose Statement

Opskarta provides a lightweight, human-readable format for representing work graphs with explicit hierarchical relationships, dependencies, and temporal planning. Unlike traditional project management tools that force you into rigid workflows, opskarta separates the "what exists" (the plan) from "how you look at it" (views), enabling different stakeholders to see relevant slices of the same underlying structure.

### Core Goals and Objectives

- **Separation of concerns**: Maintain a single source of truth for project structure while supporting multiple visualizations
- **Git-friendly format**: YAML/JSON documents that diff well and support branching workflows
- **Schema validation**: Robust validation ensuring referential integrity and business rule compliance
- **Extensible format**: Allow custom fields without breaking compatibility
- **Toolkit independence**: Provide reference implementations that others can build upon

### Target Audience

- Product managers and project leaders who need flexible, evolving project structures
- Engineering teams managing complex, multi-track programs
- Organizations seeking to integrate with existing issue tracking systems while maintaining their own structural interpretation
- Tool builders creating integrations and visualization layers

## Technical Architecture

The opskarta project follows a clean separation of concerns architecture with three primary components:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Plan Files (*.plan.yaml)] --> B[Validation Tools]
    C[Views Files (*.views.yaml)] --> B
    B --> D[Rendering Tools]
    D --> E[Mermaid Gantt]
    D --> F[Other Renderers]
    G[JSON Schemas] --> B
    H[Reference Examples] --> B
    H --> D
```

### Component Breakdown

**Specification Layer**: Defines the opskarta v1 format with clear schemas for plans and views, establishing the contract between different tools and implementations.

**Tooling Layer**: Provides reference implementations including validators, renderers, and documentation generators that demonstrate best practices for working with opskarta data.

**Integration Layer**: Enables connections with external systems like Jira, Confluence, and other project management tools through standardized interfaces.

### Design Patterns

The project employs several key design patterns:

- **Separation of Model and View**: Plans represent structure while views control presentation
- **Schema Validation Pattern**: Multiple validation levels (syntax, schema, semantics) ensure data quality
- **Plugin Architecture**: Modular rendering system allows extensible output formats
- **Reference Implementation Pattern**: Clear examples demonstrate proper usage without enforcing specific tool choices

### System Relationships

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant Author as Plan Author
    participant Validator as Validation Tool
    participant Renderer as Rendering Tool
    participant Viewer as End User
    
    Author->>+Validator: Validate plan.yaml
    Validator-->>-Author: Validation results
    Author->>+Renderer: Render views
    Renderer-->>-Author: Generated artifacts
    Author->>+Viewer: Share views
    Viewer-->>-Author: Feedback
```

## Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points

The project centers around two primary entry points:

**Validation System** (`specs/v1/tools/validate.py`): Comprehensive validation pipeline checking YAML syntax, JSON schema compliance, and semantic integrity including dependency cycles and referential consistency.

**Rendering System** (`specs/v1/tools/render/mermaid_gantt.py`): Advanced Gantt diagram generator with automatic scheduling calculation, weekend exclusion handling, and status-based theming.

### Core Modules

**Plan Processing Module** (`specs/v1/tools/validate.py`): Implements comprehensive validation logic including:
- Syntax validation using PyYAML
- JSON Schema validation (optional)
- Semantic validation for parent-child relationships
- Dependency cycle detection
- Date and duration format validation

**Scheduling Engine** (`specs/v1/tools/render/mermaid_gantt.py`): Sophisticated time calculation system supporting:
- Automatic date computation from dependencies
- Weekend exclusion logic
- Duration parsing and validation
- Hierarchical inheritance of timing attributes

**Schema Definitions** (`specs/v1/schemas/`): JSON Schema specifications ensuring consistent data modeling across implementations.

### Configuration Approach

The project uses a layered configuration system:

- **Runtime Configuration**: Command-line arguments for tools
- **Schema Configuration**: JSON Schema files defining valid structures
- **Example Configuration**: Comprehensive examples demonstrating best practices
- **Extension Configuration**: Support for custom fields through the `x:` namespace

### External Dependencies

**Required Dependencies**:
- PyYAML (6.0): Primary dependency for YAML parsing and serialization
- Python 3.8+: Runtime environment requirement

**Optional Dependencies**:
- jsonschema (4.0): Enhanced validation capabilities
- argparse: Command-line interface processing

### Integration Points

**External System Integration**:
- Issue tracking systems (Jira, YouTrack) via issue field mapping
- Version control systems through Git-friendly document format
- Visualization platforms through Mermaid export
- CI/CD pipelines for automated validation and rendering

### Component Relationships

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Plan Parser] --> B[Validation Engine]
    B --> C[Render Pipeline]
    C --> D[Output Generators]
    
    E[JSON Schema] --> B
    F[Examples] --> A
    G[CLI Tools] --> B
    G --> C
    
    H[Status Colors] --> C
    I[Date Calculators] --> C
```

## Key Features

### Functionality Overview

Opskarta provides a comprehensive solution for operational mapping with the following core capabilities:

**Hierarchical Work Structures**: Support for summary, phase, epic, and task level decomposition with parent-child relationships enabling complex multi-track programs.

**Dependency Management**: Flexible dependency specification allowing both explicit ordering and implicit inheritance from parent nodes.

**Temporal Planning**: Built-in support for start dates, durations, and automatic scheduling calculations with weekend exclusion options.

**Multi-view Visualization**: Separate view files enable different stakeholders to see relevant subsets of the complete work graph.

**Extensible Metadata**: Custom fields through the `x:` namespace allow organizations to add domain-specific information without breaking compatibility.

### Implementation Highlights

**Advanced Scheduling Algorithm** (`specs/v1/tools/render/mermaid_gantt.py`): Implements sophisticated date calculation handling dependencies, parent inheritance, and business day arithmetic.

**Comprehensive Validation Suite** (`specs/v1/tools/validate.py`): Multi-level validation covering syntax, schema compliance, and semantic integrity with detailed error reporting.

**Flexible Rendering System** (`specs/v1/tools/render/`): Pluggable renderer architecture supporting multiple output formats beyond Mermaid Gantt diagrams.

### Feature Architecture

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> PlanCreation
    PlanCreation --> Validation: Validate
    Validation --> Rendering: Valid Plan
    Validation --> PlanCreation: Fix Issues
    Rendering --> OutputGeneration: Generate Views
    OutputGeneration --> [*]
    
    PlanCreation --> Extension: Add Custom Fields
    Extension --> Validation: Re-validate
```

The opskarta ecosystem demonstrates how simple, well-designed data formats can enable complex workflows while maintaining flexibility and interoperability. Its emphasis on separating structure from presentation, combined with robust validation and extensible design, positions it as a foundation for building project management tools that truly serve organizational needs rather than constraining them.

**Sources:**
- [SPEC.md](specs/v1/SPEC.md)
- [README.md](specs/v1/tools/README.md)
- [requirements.txt](specs/v1/tools/requirements.txt)
- [hello.plan.yaml](specs/v1/examples/hello/hello.plan.yaml)
- [hello.views.yaml](specs/v1/examples/hello/hello.views.yaml)
- [mermaid_gantt.py](specs/v1/tools/render/mermaid_gantt.py)
- [validate.py](specs/v1/tools/validate.py)
- [plan.schema.json](specs/v1/schemas/plan.schema.json)
- [views.schema.json](specs/v1/schemas/views.schema.json)
- [method.md](docs/method.md)
- [program.plan.yaml](specs/v1/examples/advanced/program.plan.yaml)
- [program.views.yaml](specs/v1/examples/advanced/program.views.yaml)

</blog>
